title: Creating a Pitch Deck for Investors
headline: Learn how to create great pitch and marketing decks to convince investors in this free online entrepreneurship course.
description: A visual presentation or ‘pitch’ is a crucial tool that communicates the key elements of business ideas to potential investors and provides a roadmap. Putting all your great ideas into a presentation can be overwhelming as it’s hard to know what to leave out and which visuals and flow to use in your deck. This course teaches entrepreneurs how to create a concise and compelling pitch deck to woo potential investors for funding and partnership.
courseDescription:
A pitch deck is a brief visual presentation used by entrepreneurs and business owners to provide an overview of their business plans, products, services and growth to potential investors or clients. A pitch deck can be an extremely useful tool in business fundraising. We created this short course to walk you through the steps taken to create a compelling pitch deck that will get you to the next meeting. This entrepreneurship course begins with a brief introduction and provides insider tips for creating an effective pitch deck. We explain how to create an eye-catching ‘vision slide’ and an overview of your company, which typically includes an introduction to the company and its mission, vision, values, target market, competition and key performance indicators.

This course describes how to write a ‘problem statement’ that resonates with potential investors and a ‘solution statement’ that demonstrates your company’s valuation proposition and ability to meet your customers’ needs and desires. We identify the components of the ‘target market’ and the ‘market size’ slides and explain how to calculate the market size and the properties of the ‘competitive matrix’. We lay out the key things to consider when composing ‘competitor’, ‘business model’, ‘go-to-market’ and ‘team’ slides. Finally, we show you how to create perfect ‘financial’ and ‘traction’ slides.

This course is ideal for small business owners and startups looking for investment or partnership opportunities. It also suits entrepreneurs who have a business idea and are looking to present their project to potential investors, clients or partners. This course demonstrates how to communicate your business ideas to investors clearly and effectively and also how to show that you are serious about your business to speed up the fundraising process. This entrepreneurship gives you the inside track on the competition so sign up to learn how to impress investors with a compelling pitch deck.

Start Course Now

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • By the end of this module, you will be able to:
    • Explain the purpose and qualities of a vision statement.
    • Summarize the properties of a problem statement.
    • Recall key things to consider when creating the solution statement.
    • State the benefits of the solution statement and why it resonates most with investors.
    • Identify the key considerations when determining your market size.
    • State the key to identifying your target market.
    • Distinguish between the various categories of the market size.

  • The Target Market Slide

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary

    • The investor desk is the most important document you should have when pitching to investors. Investors are likely to not talk to you unless you have a pitch deck.
    • The goal is to get people compelled enough to move you down the chain, the further you go down the chain, the more likely you are to meet potential investors.
    • Avoid putting too much data on the slide and make sure the slide content resonates with the investors.
    • Investors usually don’t invest outside their circle, understand the cheque size they invest in.
    • A vision should be aspirational, it’s not about where you are today but about where you are going and where you want to be. It should say what you are ultimately going to become.
    • Don’t talk about the solution when creating the problem statement. This slide should be focused on your target audience or customer. Your problem statement also needs to resonate with your investor.
    • The solution statement should demonstrate your company’s valuation proposition to make your customer’s life better.
    • In order to not make your business feasible, you can broaden your focus to make sure you have a large enough to serve.
    • Guestimating on your total addressable market (TAM) is OK if you have estimates from sources that might not 100% match your market. You can use a down approach for TAM.
    • It is important that you size the source of your estimates so the investor knows they are creditable.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • By the end of this module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss the best ways to approach the competition slide.
    • Identify the steps involved in building the competitive matrix
    • State the items to be included in the product slide.
    • Summarize the purpose of the team slide.
    • List the contents of the ask and use of funds slide.
    • Explain the need for a financial forecast in the financials slide.

  • Competitive Matrix Slide

  • Financial Slide - Part 1

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary

    • The competitive matrix will always position you as the leader in the market based on how you define your market.
    • A competitive matrix is a visual representation of how you stack up against the competition of your two greatest strengths.
    • The first step in building your competitive matrix is to select your competitive strengths to measure, then select your competitors, and then evaluate and plot your competitors.
    • When selecting a competitor, it is advisable to pick 7-10 competitors, pick a wide variety of competitors, don’t just pick the weak competitors, and don’t be afraid to have competitors in the 4th quadrant.
    • When creating the business model, start by describing to the investor the price model, and tell them how you are going to charge customers.
    • It's important to spend time on the team slide, this is because investors will also invest in you and the team.
    • It is important to include relevant background like past companies of each team member in the team slide, along with educational details and a photo of each team member.
    • Financials need to be believable in that when a reasonable person looks at them, they are not so off the charts that it would take a miracle for you to achieve them.
    • The traction slide can be before the go-to-market slide and can contain a graph that shows the number of customers, sales,
